T1003.001::[APT1] has been known to use credential dumping using [Mimikatz].
T1021.001::The [APT1] group is known to have used RDP during operations.
T1036.005::The file name AcroRD32.exe, a legitimate process name for Adobe's Acrobat Reader, was used by [APT1] as a name for malware.
T1059.003::[APT1] has used the Windows command shell to execute commands, and batch scripting to automate execution.
T1087.001::[APT1] used the commands net localgroup,net user, and net group to find accounts on the system.
T1114.001::[APT1] uses two utilities, GETMAIL and MAPIGET, to steal email. GETMAIL extracts emails from archived Outlook .pst files.
T1114.002::[APT1] uses two utilities, GETMAIL and MAPIGET, to steal email. MAPIGET steals email still on Exchange servers that has not yet been archived.
T1550.002::The [APT1] group is known to have used pass the hash.
T1560.001::[APT1] has used RAR to compress files before moving them outside of the victim network.
T1566.001::[APT1] has sent spearphishing emails containing malicious attachments.
T1566.002::[APT1] has sent spearphishing emails containing hyperlinks to malicious files.
T1583.001::[APT1] has registered hundreds of domains for use in operations.
T1584.001::[APT1] hijacked FQDNs associated with legitimate websites hosted by hop points.
T1585.002::[APT1] has created email accounts for later use in social engineering, phishing, and when registering domains.
T1588.001::[APT1] used publicly available malware for privilege escalation.
T1588.002::[APT1] has used various open-source tools for privilege escalation purposes.
